content.rendered:
It’s not easy to figure out what I fear most. Snakes and grizzly bear probably top that list. I cannot say that I feel a fear of missing out because I think I’ve been there and done that. I feel no need to do the other things. Jumping out of an airplane and standing on the edge of a thousand foot cliff don’t interest me.

I used to have this feeling — something I would imagine — that a grizzly bear would come up from behind, as I got ready for bed, tap me on the shoulder and say, “Excuse me.” No, it never happened, thankfully. That kind of thing only happens in cartoons.

One of my friends in Idaho was an uncle and guardian to some wonderful children. They could scare me, running behind moving vehicles or towards busy highways.

Having other people watch me as I try to work — like when I was in cooking school — used to scare me. But I think I’ve gotten used to it, maybe.

I rented a movie. And, for me, it’s been very difficult to watch. It doesn’t show a shark attack (sharks are on my list, too) or zombies. It has a widow, a house cleaner from London, who just wants to buy a dress. It may have a happy ending, but I can only seem to watch about 15 minutes at a time.

I’ve felt some emotions in the past. Love is great, but I can remember feeling great sorrow as well. I’ve been hopeful, but I’ve also known confusion, uncertainty and, perhaps, depression. But I’ve survived them all.

Now, having survived something doesn’t mean that I don’t fear it. Often, I’ve had a feeling that something that I really wanted wasn’t going to work out. Usually, these fears are unfounded. And I’ve learned that God really is in charge of this world. If God doesn’t allow something, it’s most likely because it’s not good for me: that it’s not part of God’s plan for my life. I may not understand, but I don’t have to. I just have to trust.

Oh, I still have fears: hurting someone that I love tops that list. I still struggle with certain emotions. That’s why I tend to stick to watching cartoons: ones that are 20 minutes or less are great. The ones that can put me to sleep in under 5 minutes are better.

First John 4:18 (KJV) tells us, “There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear: because fear hath torment. He that feareth is not made perfect in love.”

Yes, I still have fears — mostly in areas of my life where my faith is still weak. But I try to focus on what I know, that God loves me and that His plans are good.
